document_metadata.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Neuronal nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) belong to a super-family of Cys- loop ligand-gated ion channels that respond to endogenous acetylcholine (ACh) or other cholinergic ligands.

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: In the brain, nAChRs are widely expressed, both presyn- aptically and postsynaptically, and are involved in several functions including learning and memory, arousal, reward, motor control, and analgesia. nAChRs are also the target of nicotine, the main addictive agent delivered by cigarette smoke

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: In the brain, nAChRs are widely expressed, both presyn- aptically and postsynaptically, and are involved in several functions including learning and memory, arousal, reward, motor control, and analgesia. nAChRs are also the target of nicotine, the main addictive agent delivered by cigarette smoke

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: In the brain, nAChRs are widely expressed, both presyn- aptically and postsynaptically, and are involved in several functions including learning and memory, arousal, reward, motor control, and analgesia. nAChRs are also the target of nicotine, the main addictive agent delivered by cigarette smoke

links.evidence: In the brain, nAChRs are widely expressed, both presyn- aptically and postsynaptically, and are involved in several functions including learning and memory, arousal, reward, motor control, and analgesia. nAChRs are also the target of nicotine, the main addictive agent delivered by cigarette smoke

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: nAChRs are expressed also at the somatodendritic postsynaptic site, where they regulate neuron depolarisation, firing and long- term potentiation [9]. Moreover these receptors are also in- volved in proliferation, differentiation and migration of neu- ral progenitors

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: nAChRs are expressed also at the somatodendritic postsynaptic site, where they regulate neuron depolarisation, firing and long- term potentiation [9]. Moreover these receptors are also in- volved in proliferation, differentiation and migration of neu- ral progenitors

links.evidence: nAChRs are expressed also at the somatodendritic postsynaptic site, where they regulate neuron depolarisation, firing and long- term potentiation [9]. Moreover these receptors are also in- volved in proliferation, differentiation and migration of neu- ral progenitors

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: nAChRs contribute to cognitive function, and changes in their number and/or func- tion are associated with various pathological conditions such as cognitive disorders, anxiety, depression, Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease, pain and epilepsy

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: nAChRs contribute to cognitive function, and changes in their number and/or func- tion are associated with various pathological conditions such as cognitive disorders, anxiety, depression, Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease, pain and epilepsy

links.evidence: nAChRs contribute to cognitive function, and changes in their number and/or func- tion are associated with various pathological conditions such as cognitive disorders, anxiety, depression, Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease, pain and epilepsy

links.evidence: nAChRs contribute to cognitive function, and changes in their number and/or func- tion are associated with various pathological conditions such as cognitive disorders, anxiety, depression, Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease, pain and epilepsy

links.evidence: nAChRs contribute to cognitive function, and changes in their number and/or func- tion are associated with various pathological conditions such as cognitive disorders, anxiety, depression, Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease, pain and epilepsy

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: nAChRs contribute to cognitive function, and changes in their number and/or func- tion are associated with various pathological conditions such as cognitive disorders, anxiety, depression, Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease, pain and epilepsy

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: nAChRs contribute to cognitive function, and changes in their number and/or func- tion are associated with various pathological conditions such as cognitive disorders, anxiety, depression, Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease, pain and epilepsy

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: nAChRs are particularly important in two critical periods of brain life: early pre- and post-natal circuit formation, and age-related cell degeneration. They are involved in neuronal survival, as it has been shown that nicotinic agonists are neu- roprotective in in vivo and in vitro models

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: The Hb-IPN system expresses the highest levels and variety of nAChR subunits and subtypes in mammalian brain [85], and is the only central system expressing high levels of α3, β4 and α5 subunits.

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Neuronal nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) belong to a super-family of Cys- loop ligand-gated ion channels that respond to endogenous acetylcholine (ACh) or other cholinergic ligands.

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: but ACh is also released by non-neuronal tissues where it is involved in cell-to-cell communication, and controls essential functions such as cell proliferation, adhesion, migration, secretion, survival and apoptosis, in an autocrine, paracrine or juxtacrine manner

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: but ACh is also released by non-neuronal tissues where it is involved in cell-to-cell communication, and controls essential functions such as cell proliferation, adhesion, migration, secretion, survival and apoptosis, in an autocrine, paracrine or juxtacrine manner

links.evidence: but ACh is also released by non-neuronal tissues where it is involved in cell-to-cell communication, and controls essential functions such as cell proliferation, adhesion, migration, secretion, survival and apoptosis, in an autocrine, paracrine or juxtacrine manner

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Together with that re- leased by vagal nerve endings, ACh can also contribute to the cholinergic control of inflammation

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: When lung cancer arises from the airway epithelium, cell growth is stimulated by ACh or nicotine, and this growth loop may provide endogenous mitogenic signalling without any further activation

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: α9 and α9-α10 nAChRs have a number of interesting characteristics: they are acti- vated by ACh but not by the classical agonist nicotine. Cho- line is also a potent selective agonist of the α9 subtype

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: α9 and α9-α10 nAChRs have a number of interesting characteristics: they are acti- vated by ACh but not by the classical agonist nicotine. Cho- line is also a potent selective agonist of the α9 subtype

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: The neurotransmitter acetylcholine (ACh) is synthesised, stored and released by cholinergic neurons, and exerts its effects on the central nervous system (CNS) and peripheral nervous system (PNS) through two distinct types of receptor: the muscarinic and nicotinic ACh receptors (mAChRs and nAChRs).

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: The binding of ACh or nicotine activates neuronal nAChRs thus leading to the influx of Na+ and Ca2+ and ef- flux of K+.

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: The binding of ACh or nicotine activates neuronal nAChRs thus leading to the influx of Na+ and Ca2+ and ef- flux of K+.

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: The binding of ACh or nicotine activates neuronal nAChRs thus leading to the influx of Na+ and Ca2+ and ef- flux of K+.

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: These receptors are also the targets of drugs such as nicotine (the main addictive agent delivered by cigarette smoke) and are involved in a variety of physiological and pathophysiological processes.

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: α4β2* subtypes, in which the presence of different accessory subunits changes their pharmacological and biophysical properties, and their sensitivity to allosteric modulators and up-regulation by nicotine

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: By activating the α4β2 receptors on inhibitory GABAergic inputs to the VTA or GABAergic interneurons, smoked concentrations of nicotine transiently increase the release of GABA and subse- quently depress it for about one hour

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Chronic nicotine treatment also activates the α7 receptors expressed on glutamatergic terminals, increases the release of glutamate (which facilitates the burst firing of VTA DA neurons), increases NMDA receptor activity, and LTP [79], but simultaneosusly induces the desensitisation of the α4β2 receptors on GABAergic terminals. Overall, these effects decrease the inhibition onto DA neurons, and increase DA release in the NAc [82].

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: nAChRs are particularly important in two critical periods of brain life: early pre- and post-natal circuit formation, and age-related cell degeneration. They are involved in neuronal survival, as it has been shown that nicotinic agonists are neu- roprotective in in vivo and in vitro models

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Chronic nicotine exposure induces neural adaptations that change cell physi- ology and behaviour mainly as a result of activation and/or desensitisation of nAChRs. Studies of the brains of animals and smokers chronically exposed to nicotine have shown an increase in the number of nAChRs (up-regulation).

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: There is evidence indicating that key steps in nicotine-induced up-regulation are receptor assem- bly [72, 73], decreased proteasomal degradation [74], traf- ficking [75] and cell surface expression

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: There is evidence indicating that key steps in nicotine-induced up-regulation are receptor assem- bly [72, 73], decreased proteasomal degradation [74], traf- ficking [75] and cell surface expression

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: By acting on the α7 receptors in glutamate terminals, acutely administrated nicotine stimu- lates the release of glutamate, which facilitates the burst fir- ing of VTA DA neurons and eventually leads to LTP,and increases the firing rate of the GABAergic neurons of the rostromedial tegmental nucleus

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Chronic nicotine treatment also activates the α7 receptors expressed on glutamatergic terminals, increases the release of glutamate (which facilitates the burst firing of VTA DA neurons), increases NMDA receptor activity, and LTP [79], but simultaneosusly induces the desensitisation of the α4β2 receptors on GABAergic terminals. Overall, these effects decrease the inhibition onto DA neurons, and increase DA release in the NAc [82].

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: By activating the α4β2 receptors on inhibitory GABAergic inputs to the VTA or GABAergic interneurons, smoked concentrations of nicotine transiently increase the release of GABA and subse- quently depress it for about one hour

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: By activating the α4β2 receptors on inhibitory GABAergic inputs to the VTA or GABAergic interneurons, smoked concentrations of nicotine transiently increase the release of GABA and subse- quently depress it for about one hour

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: nicotine modulates the shift towards burst firing and increases DA release in the NAc

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: nicotine modulates the shift towards burst firing and increases DA release in the NAc

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Chronic nicotine treatment also activates the α7 receptors expressed on glutamatergic terminals, increases the release of glutamate (which facilitates the burst firing of VTA DA neurons), increases NMDA receptor activity, and LTP [79], but simultaneosusly induces the desensitisation of the α4β2 receptors on GABAergic terminals. Overall, these effects decrease the inhibition onto DA neurons, and increase DA release in the NAc [82].

links.evidence: Chronic nicotine treatment also activates the α7 receptors expressed on glutamatergic terminals, increases the release of glutamate (which facilitates the burst firing of VTA DA neurons), increases NMDA receptor activity, and LTP [79], but simultaneosusly induces the desensitisation of the α4β2 receptors on GABAergic terminals. Overall, these effects decrease the inhibition onto DA neurons, and increase DA release in the NAc [82].

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: These alterations are very similar to those observed in cul- tured human airway cells or in ex vivo human lung explants treated with the selective α7 antagonist αBgtx, or epithelial cell cultures chronically exposed to nicotine in which nico- tine-induced desensitisation of α7 receptors mimics the ab- sence of α7 nAChR

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Chronic nicotine treatment also activates the α7 receptors expressed on glutamatergic terminals, increases the release of glutamate (which facilitates the burst firing of VTA DA neurons), increases NMDA receptor activity, and LTP [79], but simultaneosusly induces the desensitisation of the α4β2 receptors on GABAergic terminals. Overall, these effects decrease the inhibition onto DA neurons, and increase DA release in the NAc [82].

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Chronic nicotine treatment also activates the α7 receptors expressed on glutamatergic terminals, increases the release of glutamate (which facilitates the burst firing of VTA DA neurons), increases NMDA receptor activity, and LTP [79], but simultaneosusly induces the desensitisation of the α4β2 receptors on GABAergic terminals. Overall, these effects decrease the inhibition onto DA neurons, and increase DA release in the NAc [82].

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: The coding SNP α5 D398N is closely associated with nicotine consumption

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Finally, a study has shown that α2 Ko mice have enhanced nicotine self-administration behaviour [88]. These findings suggest that α5* nAChRs in the MHb, and α2* nAChRs in the IPN may underlie aversive responses to nicotine.

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Finally, a study has shown that α2 Ko mice have enhanced nicotine self-administration behaviour [88]. These findings suggest that α5* nAChRs in the MHb, and α2* nAChRs in the IPN may underlie aversive responses to nicotine.

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Once in the bloodstream, nicotine, rapidly crosses the blood/brain barrier, and accumulates and exerts its pharmacological effects [9, 58] (including psy- chostimulation, reward and the reduction of stress and anxi- ety) in the brain by binding to nAChRs.

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Accordingly, ACh and its synthesizing enzyme choline acetyltransferase (ChAT), are found in human and animal erythrocytes, immune cells, endothelial and epithelial cells (including airway epithelial cells) and placenta cells. Small amounts of ACh are even found in blood

links.evidence: whereas those on microglia increase intracellular calcium levels and signalling cascades without using channel function, and those on macrophages and other immunological cells signal through the JAK2/STAT3 tran- scription factor pathway

links.evidence: In heterologous sys- tems, α7 subunits form functional channels with the β2 [29], β3 [30], β4 [31], or α5 subunit [32].

links.evidence: The Hb-IPN system expresses the highest levels and variety of nAChR subunits and subtypes in mammalian brain [85], and is the only central system expressing high levels of α3, β4 and α5 subunits.

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Functional studies have shown that α7dup, expressed in oo- cytes, acts as a dominant negative regulator of α7 nAChR activity by means of a mechanism involving a reduction in the number of functional α7 nAChRs incorporated into the oocyte surface

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: nAChRs are expressed also at the somatodendritic postsynaptic site, where they regulate neuron depolarisation, firing and long- term potentiation [9]. Moreover these receptors are also in- volved in proliferation, differentiation and migration of neu- ral progenitors

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: nAChRs contribute to cognitive function, and changes in their number and/or func- tion are associated with various pathological conditions such as cognitive disorders, anxiety, depression, Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease, pain and epilepsy

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: nAChRs are particularly important in two critical periods of brain life: early pre- and post-natal circuit formation, and age-related cell degeneration. They are involved in neuronal survival, as it has been shown that nicotinic agonists are neu- roprotective in in vivo and in vitro models

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: The up- regulation of nAChRs has also been obtained using nicotinic agonists (cytisine, carbamylcholine and varenicline) [66, 67], antagonists (dihydro-β-erythroidine, mecamylamine) [68-70] and a partial agonist (CC4)

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Dopamine (DA) neurons, which project to the NAc receive both excitatory glutamater- gic and cholinergic afferents that mediate nicotine reward, and inhibitory GABAergic afferents, that mediate aversion [77]. The release of these neurotransmitters is modulated by the nAChRs expressed in cholinergic, glutamatergic and GABAergic terminals

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: By acting on the α7 receptors in glutamate terminals, acutely administrated nicotine stimu- lates the release of glutamate, which facilitates the burst fir- ing of VTA DA neurons and eventually leads to LTP,and increases the firing rate of the GABAergic neurons of the rostromedial tegmental nucleus

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: The coding SNP α5 D398N is closely associated with nicotine consumption

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: α5 subunit Ko mice or mice with selective knock down of the α5 subunits in the Hb develop increased nicotine intake in a self-administration paradigm that is blocked by the selective re-expression of the α5 subunit within the MHb; thus indicating that the α5-containing nAChRs located in this brain area also play an important role in regulating the negative effects of nicotine.

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: On the contrary the overexpression of β4* nAChRs in mice decreases nico- tine reinforcing properties and consumption

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: The cytoplasmic in- crease in calcium triggers the secretion of mitogenic factors and activates the signalling cascades involved in cell prolif- eration, migration and angiogenesis and the inhibition of apoptosis

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Non-neuronal cholinergic signalling uses the same nAChRs as neuronal cholinergic signalling and the nAChRs in both neuronal and non-neuronal networks are modulated by members of the ly-6 family of small proteins related to snake α-neurotoxins such as the α7 nAChR antagonist αBgtx

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: These proteins include Lynx1, a glycophosphati- dylinositol- anchored membrane protein that can form a sta- ble complex, negatively regulates the responses of α4β2 and α7 nAChRs in heterologous systems and enhances the rate and extent of desensitisation of α4β2 nAChRs, thus acting as a molecular brake on nAChR function

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: These proteins include Lynx1, a glycophosphati- dylinositol- anchored membrane protein that can form a sta- ble complex, negatively regulates the responses of α4β2 and α7 nAChRs in heterologous systems and enhances the rate and extent of desensitisation of α4β2 nAChRs, thus acting as a molecular brake on nAChR function

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: The α5 subunit, which is the product of the CHRNA5 gene, has been shown to form functional channels when it is associated with the α4 and β2 or α3 and β4 subunits

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: The α5 subunit, which is the product of the CHRNA5 gene, has been shown to form functional channels when it is associated with the α4 and β2 or α3 and β4 subunits

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Human genetic studies have shown that the non- synonymous coding SNP D398N is associated with lung cancer and nicotine dependence

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Lee et al. [122] have found that α9 nAChRs are ubiquitously expressed in many epithe- lial, lung and breast cancer cell lines, most of which also express α5 and α10 nAChR subunits. α9 nAChRs are also present in primary tumour and non-malignant breast tissue obtained from patients, but their expression is higher in breast cancer cells than the surrounding normal tissue.

links.evidence: Airway epithelium cells synthesise, store, process, se- crete and reabsorb ACh, which acts as an autocrine and paracrine growth factor

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: α7 nAChRs are essential for the plasticity of the airway epithelium as α7 Ko mice show altered basal cell layer formation, hyperplasia, and uncontrolled growth

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: α7 nAChRs are essential for the plasticity of the airway epithelium as α7 Ko mice show altered basal cell layer formation, hyperplasia, and uncontrolled growth

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Unlike the α9 subunit, the α10 subunit is only functional when it is co-expressed with an α9 subunit. In Xenopus oocytes, the co-injection of α9 and α10 subunits increases functional nAChR expression at least 100 times more than the injection of α9 alone.

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: Si- lencing α9 nAChR expression in the tumour cells reduces their proliferation and tumorigenic potential in in vitro and in vivo assays [122].

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: α9 and α9-α10 nAChRs have a number of interesting characteristics: they are acti- vated by ACh but not by the classical agonist nicotine. Cho- line is also a potent selective agonist of the α9 subtype

citation.name: Neuronal and Extraneuronal Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors.

links.evidence: whereas phosphocholine (PC) does not evoke ion current responses in Xenopus oocytes expressing functional ho- momeric α9 or heteromeric α9-α10 nAChRs [121]. How- ever, preincubation with PC attenuates choline-induced ion current changes, thus suggesting that PC is a silent agonist of these two subtypes
